comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: Here is link to Wikipedia bio of then king of Spain, Alfonso XIII, sure looks to be the same guy. (But who is "Seade Moulin", maybe refers to the two gentlemen on the left)? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfonso_XIII_of_Spain

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Looks like it might say "Jean De Moulin," but I can't find anything under that name, either.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: In May 1913, Alfonso visited President Poincaré of France in Paris. See NYT of May 8, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D07E5D91F3AE633A... "PARIS, May 7. -- King Alfonso of Spain arrived in Paris this morning on a three days' visit to President Poincare. He and Count Romanones, the Spanish Premier, drove from the station with the President in a four-horse carriage, escorted by cuirassiers." This could certainly be in Paris and I think the soldiers could be cuirassiers.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Swanq: Thanks!  This certainly looks probable.  We'll fix the date and title in the source data and reload the description

comment.author: 13070533@N07
comment._content: I think the title should probably read: "Beaudemoulin, King of Spain, Poincaré" as général de brigade Antoine Beaudemoulin (1857-1927) was the head of the president's millitary staff (secrétaire général de la Présidence et chef de la Maison Militaire du Président de la République). He was certainly present during the visit of Alfonso XIII.

comment.author: 13070533@N07
comment._content: Thanks swanq - I forgot to add the link to the source. Incidentally, the escort aren't cuirassiers, as they are not wearing the cuirass. The white cuff patch and the fact that the rear soldier appears to be holding a lance suggests that they could be dragoons.
